Tom --

Re: Iron Dragon Tsuba -- Photos in folder entitled SOSIDORE

The ca=
ptioned tsuba could be an artifact that can best illustrate 
the historical=
 cultural exchange between China and Japan before 
first Sino-Japanese war.=
 
Japan used to send contribution to Chinese emperors since as long 
ago as=
 8th century A.D. And swords were among the list of Japanese 
contributions=
. In return China had Japanese delegate brought home 
much much more than t=
hey gave. I did not invent stories like this. 
Chinese history had had ampl=
e records about them. I would believe 
that in Tokyo palace vault there are=
 tremendous number of treasury 
that once were gifts from Chinese emperors.=
 They must have been well 
documented. Japanese gives and takes. I wish som=
eday Chinese 
friendship contributions could be made possible for all to se=
e. 
Now, why am I so sure that the captioned tsuba was made in Japan? 
Apar=
t from material, workmanship and style in general, the most 
obvious point =
in focus is the mustach of the dragon. The dragon on 
this tsuba is thick w=
ith mustach. That is what so unique about it. 
Please try to take a strong =
view on Meiji silver one-yen coin. The 
Japanese dragon design on the said =
coin is thick with mustach, too. 
There should be no one challenge the auth=
enticity of Japanese dragon 
on Japanese one-yen Meiji silver coin. In case=
 of Chinese dragon, 
the dragons are mustach free since Ming and Ching dyna=
sty. 
Interesting parties will please visit two web pages listed below. 
Th=
ey are equally authentically emperial style in China. Please note 
the drag=
ons there. No mustach.
http://www.wallcoo.com/photograph/chinese_culture/ht=
ml/image50.html
http://tya.myrime.com/cgi-bin/view.cgi?forum=3D5&topic=3D29=
63
I would like to suggest something here. The implication of my 
finding p=
oint out an interesting direction for tsuba collectors to 
pursue. Some tsu=
bas used to bear a mission of introducing things 
Japan to foreign people. =
Japan was on the rice during Meiji period. 
They were eager to introduce th=
emselves to the world. Next time when 
you are about to make a choice of co=
llection take a strong view and 
think. Is this tsuba specially made with p=
eople like me in mind? If 
you do then you hold a mysterious key that could=
 open a cross time 
dialog with the original creator far away and long ago =
in a country 
call Japan.  

Happy New Year.

Ying-Chaw
Taipei
